titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cormac K. H. O’Malley Papers AIA.019
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Meaghan Dwyer and Mary Krinock. Finding Aid by: Meaghan Dwyer, Mary Krinock, Marion R. Casey and Rebecca Altermatt.

did.unittitle: Cormac K. H. O'Malley Papers

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 6 record cartons, 6 manuscript boxes, 7 oversize flat boxes, and 1 photograph box

did.abstract: Cormac K. H. O’Malley (1942-) is an attorney who has been an international corporate counsel and consultant. From the 1960s through the 1980s, O’Malley was active in the New York Irish community, joining various cultural, academic and social organizations. This collection includes materials regarding Irish-American and Irish cultural, educational, charitable, historical and political affairs. Materials include correspondence, newsletters, brochures and promotional material for the American Committee for Ulster Justice, the Irish American Cultural Institute, and the Irish American National Bicentennial Committee. Also included are articles and texts about the Northern Ireland political and military crisis during the 1970s and lobbying material for the 1972 U.S. Congressional Hearings on Northern Ireland. O’Malley collected the materials through his contacts with various organizations in the Irish communities in New York, Boston, and Dublin, and his involvement with the struggle for civil rights in Northern Ireland.
did.physloc: Materials stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact irishamerica.archives@nyu.edu two business days prior to research visit.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: In 1980 Cormac O’Malley deposited 27 cubic feet of material in the archives of St. John’s University in Jamaica, New York. It remained unprocessed and unused for the next 20 years. In December 2000, while President of the Board of Advisors for New York University’s Glucksman Ireland House, O’Malley transferred the collection to the Archives of Irish America at the Tamiment Library as a permanent donation.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Cormac Kevin Hooker O’Malley was born in Dublin, Ireland in 1942. His father was Ernie O'Malley (1897-1957), Irish revolutionary, author and patron of the arts, and his mother was American artist and socialite Helen Huntington Hooker (1905-1993). Upon the death of his father, O’Malley left Ireland to finish his education in the United States, obtaining a BA from Harvard in 1965 and a JD from Columbia University in 1970. He pursued a career in international law in New York, first with Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle, then, from 1981 with Bristol-Myers, living in Mexico, Brussels, London, and New York according to the dictates of his career. In the 1990s, upon retirement from Bristol-Myers Squibb, O’Malley became active as an advisor to Glucksman Ireland House at New York University.

When in New York, O’Malley was involved with the Irish American community, joining various cultural, academic, and social organizations, such as the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, the American Committee (later Conference) for Irish Studies, and the Irish Arts Center in New York. During the 1970s-1980s, O’Malley served as an officer or on the board of four such groups: the American Irish Historical Society, the Irish American National Bicentennial Committee, the Ireland Fund (now the American Ireland Fund) and the National University of Ireland Club. O’Malley also had an interest in the civil rights struggle in Northern Ireland. From 1971-1978 he served as national coordinator for the American Committee for Ulster Justice, a group of Irish American lawyers and activists intent on eliminating anti-Catholic discrimination and exposing British complicity in the region's conflict.

O'Malley is the author of "The Publication History of On Another Man's Wound" in New Hibernia Review7:3 (2003): 136-139 and co-author with Keith Highet of Current Aspects of Doing Business in Black Africa(American Bar Association, 1975).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of material included in this collection reflects O’Malley’s involvement in various Irish American cultural, social, academic, and political organizations between 1964 and 1981. Materials include memoranda, transcripts, correspondence, posters, publications, scrapbooks, promotional materials, research notes, and newspaper clippings. The collection documents various aspects of Irish American social and cultural life, with materials concerning specific cultural or academic organizations. Also present are materials concerning efforts to lessen conflict in Northern Ireland during the Troubles, with specific emphasis on the American Committee for Ulster Justice.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series with eight sub-series, as follows:
Series I. Cultural, Social, and Academic Organizations, 1964-1981
Subseries IB. American Irish Historical Society (AIHS)
Subseries IC. Irish American Cultural Institute (IACI)
Subseries ID. Irish American National Bicentennial Committee
Subseries IE. National University of Ireland Club
Series II. American Committee for Ulster Justice (ACUJ), 1968-1981
Subseries IIB. U.S. Congressional Hearings on Northern Ireland
Subseries IIC. ACUJ Research Materials for 1972 Congressional Hearings
Series I, IIA, and IV are arranged alphabetically; Series IIB and IIC and III are arranged chronologically.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

list.item: Archives of Irish America Periodicals Collection AIA 004
Archives of Irish America Vertical File Collection AIA 013

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: A small collection of pamphlets and other publications regarding the struggle for recognition of the Irish Republic collected by O’Malley’s father Ernie O’Malley (1897-1957) have been removed to the AIA Pamphlet Collection (AIA 047). Promotional material, event programs, brochures and newsletters O’Malley collected from various Irish American organizations have been integrated into the AIA Vertical Files (AIA 013), AIA Peridocials Collection (AIA 004), and the Irish Republicanism Collection (AIA 022).

did.unittitle: Series I. Cultural, Social and Academic Organizations
Subseries IA. General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of correspondence, promotional materials, bulletins, and notes about several Irish and Irish American cultural, charitable, education, and academic organizations of which O’Malley was an officer or member, including the American Irish Foundation, An Taisce (National Trust of Ireland), and the Canadian Association for Irish Studies. Of particular note are folders concerning the New York Shakespeare Festival’s 1973 memorial to Jack MacGrowan and the 1975 donation of the James A. Healy Collection to the Sligo Museum and Library.

Subseries IB: American Irish Historical Society (AIHS)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of materials related to the activities of the American Irish Historical Society during the period in which O’Malley was directly involved in the organization (1968-1981). Materials relate to the society’s library and art collection. The subseries also includes an index to the Journal of the American Irish Historical Society drafted by O’Malley in 1974.

Subseries IC: Irish American Cultural Institute (IACI)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of materials concerning the Irish American Cultural Institute (founded in St. Paul, Minnesota in 1962) during the period in which O’Malley was directly involved in the organization (1967-1981). Materials relate to the organization’s Irish Fortnight Series of lectures in New York which brought over speakers from Ireland to discuss a variety of cultural topics.

Subseries ID: Irish American National Bicentennial Committee (IANBC)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of materials concerning the Irish American National Bicentennial Committee (1973-1978), established to involve Irish Americans in the activities surrounding the 200th anniversary of the founding of the United States. The organization had chapters in several states through which it sponsored events and projects, such as the participation of the Irish tall ship Creidne in Operation Sail. Of note in this subseries is O’Malley’s “Planning Guide to the Irish American Bicentennial Celebration in Your Community” (1975) and an index card file of select people in the Irish American community living on the East Coast.

Series II. American Committee for Ulster Justice (ACUJ)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of organizational and research materials generated by O’Malley while he served as national coordinator for the American Committee for Ulster Justice (ACUJ) between 1971-1978. Established by Irish American lawyers and activists in response to civil rights violations in Northern Ireland, the ACUJ focused on educating and lobbying American politicians to intercede with the British government. Materials in this series include correspondence, memoranda, publications, research notes, press releases, newspaper clippings, transcripts of Congressional hearings, and position papers released by the British and Irish governments.

did.unittitle: Subseries IIA. ACUJ Organizational Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of correspondence, memoranda, publications, research notes, and press releases related to the regular activities and the functions of the ACUJ.

Subseries IIB. U.S. Congressional Hearings on Northern Ireland

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of materials concerning the ACUJ’s participation in a Congressional hearing before the House of Representatives’ Foreign Affairs Subcommittee held in the aftermath of the Bloody Sunday shootings in 1972. Materials include correspondence, newsletters, press releases, research notes, transcripts of statements, and information concerning the Kennedy-Ribicoff Resolutions on Violence in Northern Ireland.

Subseries IIC. ACUJ Research Materials for 1972 Congressional Hearings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of research materials used to inform the ACUJ’s testimony in the Congressional hearing before the House of Representatives’ Foreign Affairs Subcommittee held in the aftermath of the Bloody Sunday shootings in 1972. Included are extensive newspaper clippings from Irish and American newspapers and magazines, transcripts of the Parliament of Northern Ireland debates (1971-1972), and statements made by individuals to the Association for Legal Justice in Belfast that same winter. Of note are the 1972 platforms of the American Democratic and Republican political parties with respect to the situation in Northern Ireland, position papers released by the British and Irish governments, the Amnesty International Report of an Enquiry into Allegations of Ill-Treatment in Northern Ireland, and press coverage concerning St. Patrick’s Day in the wake of the 1972 Congressional hearing.

Series III. Publications and Clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a variety of publications and clippings from American and Irish sources regarding Irish America, Ireland, and Northern Ireland. Of note are two folders concerning the American Bicentennial in 1976 and the connections between Ireland and the United States. The series also contaisn copies of the Hibernia Fortnightly Review, a bi-weekly publication from Dublin.

Series IV. Ephemera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of posters and two scrapbooks that O’Malley acquired or created. One scrapbook, assembled by James A. Healy in 1957, relates to James Brendan Connolly (1868-1957), a South Boston athlete who competed and won at the 1896 Olympics. The other scrapbook focuses on William Butler Yeats and the Sligo Museum, also with a connection to Healy. The posters in this series announce various musical, political, and cultural events beginning in the 1980s.
